block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''ARABIAN NIGHTS.'' Youngsters won't have to jump aboard a magic carpet and ride to an exotic desert kingdom to hear these stories, presented by the Young Vic Theater Company. The stage action takes place on an enchanted circle of sand and features nine actors who transform themselves into maidens, rocks and goblins. New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan. Tonight and Thursday night at 7; tomorrow at 1 and 7 p.m.; Sunday at noon and 6 p.m. Through Oct. 22. Tickets: $10, $20 and $25. Reservations: (212) 239-6200.

''IMAGINATION,'' a 40-minute interactive play by Elizabeth Anne Keiser in which the cast members ask the audience questions about imagination, act out ideas, portray the colors of the rainbow and play a matching game. Tomorrow and Sunday at 2 and 4 p.m. Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, Clinton. Tickets: $10; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 307-9467.

PAPAGENO PUPPET THEATER presents two productions with Susan Delery Whedon, a puppeteer and singer: ''Hansel and Gretel,'' the fairy tale, with music by Humperdinck (at 11:30 a.m.) and ''Puff the Magic Dragon,'' with music by Peter, Paul and Mary (2:30 p.m.). Saturdays and Sundays through Oct. 29 at 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street. Tickets: $6. Reservations: (212) 874-3297.

''THE SWINEHERD,'' the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale about a materialistic princess, adapted by Morna Murphy Martell. Vital Theater Company, 432 West 42nd Street, third floor, Clinton. Saturdays at 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. through Nov. 4. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 592-4508.
Events

CENTRAL PARK HISTORY HUNT, a walking tour for children ages 7 to 10, tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon, meeting at the statue of Gen. William T. Sherman, northwest corner of 59th Street and Fifth Avenue. Jane Cowan, an environmental educator, will provide a brief history of the park and its architecture. The tour, sponsored by Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts, will end at Conservatory Water, Central Park's famous model boat pond, where there will be a short reading from E. B. White's book ''Stuart Little'' and children will construct model boats and set them afloat. Children must be accompanied by an adult. Admission: $12 ($10 for members); $5 a child. Reservations required: (212) 535-2526.

FAMILY FUN DAY AT THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF DESIGN, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, tomorrow at 2:30 p.m., for children ages 3 to 8 and their adult companions. The event will begin with a tour of the academy's latest exhibition, ''Rave Reviews: American Art and Its Critics,'' followed by a reading of ''Norman the Doorman,'' the story of an artistic mouse who secretly enters a sculpture in a museum competition. Admission: $6; $4 for Friends of the Academy. Reservations and information: (212) 369-4880, extension 225.

KIDS' COMPANY AUDITIONS. Auditions for a dance company for youngsters 11 to 18 years old. Joining the troupe means a chance to work with the renowned choreographers Twyla Tharp and Mark Morris. Company members rehearse on Wednesday and Saturday afternoons. Prior dance experience is helpful, along with sports or gymnastic backgrounds for the boys. Tomorrow (and Oct. 14) from 3 to 5 p.m., in the Berkeley Carroll School, 181 Lincoln Place (between Seventh and Eighth Avenues), Park Slope, Brooklyn. Information: (718) 622-1810.

''LEAF MOTELS AND RESTAURANTS.'' Participants will observe how animals use autumn leaves in a family science workshop at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Place, Crown Heights, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. Suggested admission: $4. Information: (718) 735-4400.

''A MEDIEVAL FAIRE.'' Connie Gretz's Secret Garden, a whimsical garden based on Frances Hodgson Burnett's children's classic, at the Staten Island Botanical Garden, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, will be the site of the fair, Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Performances include the New York Scottish Pipes, Drums and Dances, medieval music and the Newcastle Infantrie doing combat. There will be a palm reader, face painters, a Black Death Fire Sale and, of course, a live joust on horseback. Admission: $4; $3 for the elderly, students with identification and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.

''READING FUNDAY,'' tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the South Street Seaport, Pier 17, Main Stage, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan. The public television station WLIW, Channel 21, will encourage children to turn off the video games and turn on to books with a day of nonstop stories, drawings, dancing, songs and giveaways. Celebrity readers include Robin Ahrens, author of ''My Building'' (11 a.m.); the singer and actress Cyndi Lauper (3 p.m.); and from PBS, ''Pappy Drewitt'' of the PBS show ''Pappyland'' (1 p.m.) and Lionel of ''Between the Lions'' (1:30 p.m.). Free. Information: (516) 367-2100, extension 8044.

''PIED PIPER FANTASY.'' Conor Nelson, a sophomore at the Manhattan School of Music, will be the featured flutist in the John Corigliano theater piece, tomorrow at 8 p.m. in the school's John C. Borden Auditorium, 120 Claremont Avenue, at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights. The concert opens with a reading of Robert Browning's poem ''The Pied Piper of Hamlin.'' To get into the spirit, Mr. Borden, who plays the Pied Piper, will dress in an ornate feathered hat and sweeping cape. He will be joined in the final section of the piece by a group of young pipers and drummers from the school's preparatory division. David Gilbert will conduct the concert, which is free. Information: (212) 749-2802, extension 528.

''VIKINGS RETURN.'' Visitors to the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street, Lower Manhattan, tomorrow through Monday can get a look at a replica of the Viking ship Islendigur, which recently crossed the Atlantic, and talk to the captain and crew members about what it's like to travel in the Viking manner. There will also be musical performances and art workshops from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Children's Center, 165 John Street. No registration required. There is a $6 materials fee for the crafts workshops. Information: (212) 748-8758.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, will feature activities celebrating the fall weather. Tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., youngsters will look for migrating hawks and create hawk constructions for gliding across the lawns with the help of autumn breezes. Tomorrow from 2:30 to 3:30 p.m., the storyteller Ron Sopyla will read the Chinese folk tale ''The Girl Who Grew Wings.'' Tomorrow at 11 a.m., visitors should bring binoculars to watch hawks and learn how to identify the more common raptors. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200; reservations: extension 213.
Exhibitions

''BABAR AND THE SUCCOTASH BIRD,'' an exhibition closing tomorrow at the Mary Ryan Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, second floor, Manhattan, featuring the first new Babar book in seven years, in the form of 18 original watercolors drawn by the author and illustrator, Laurent de Brunhoff. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Information: (212) 397-0669.

THE INVENTOR CENTER, Children's Museum of Manhattan, Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street. Recent products from the next generation of inventors: a car with helicopter blades, a mechanical glove that contains school supplies, and a Duck-a-Phone, which quacks instead of rings. Featuring 10 computer work stations, the center is a high-tech idea laboratory in which children use software to realize their creations. Each hourlong workshop is limited to children 6 and older accompanied by adults. There are many workshops on weekends; registration is required. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with museum admission: $6; $3 for the elderly; under 1, free. Information: (212) 721-1234.

''WILLIAM WEGMAN: CANES ECCLESIORUM'' (that's Latin for church dogs) is an exhibition of the photographer's famous pooches doing amazing humanlike things, created especially for the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, through Oct. 22. Free. Information: (212) 316-7540.
Zoos

''FALL FOLIAGE FESTIVAL'' at the Queens Zoo, 53-51 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, tomorrow and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Activities to celebrate autumn include a hike through the zoo to learn how seasonal changes affect plants and animals (11 a.m., 1 and 3 p.m.), meeting a barn owl, turtle or prairie dog (1 and 3 p.m.), and storytelling about trees and the animals that live in them (Wild Room at 12:30 a.m., 1:30, 2:30 and 3:30 p.m.). At crafts workshops visitors will make pop-up dioramas or animal buttons out of fall leaves. Weekend hours: 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Free with admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 271-1500.
